body:
Thank you very much for your submission.

Please format your entry according to the rules specified in [contributing.md](https://github.com/herrbischoff/awesome-osx-command-line/blob/master/contributing.md), especially with regard to capitalization.
Thanks, I had to clean it up a bit to merge it.
Gah, yea sorry. I did see that, but you beat me to it.
I really would have liked to give you proper credit but resolving merge conflicts on the command line apparently won't honor the original authors' id.
The Apple Remote Desktop ARDAgent can be configured using the  Kickstart command to set Apple Remote Desktop preferences using terminal.
Basically a nice addition, thank you, however the Markdown headline hierarchy is wrong.

Thanks for the quick feedback. 
The headline hierarchy should now be correct.
sorin-iconescu/prezto is abandoned, see https://github.com/sorin-ionescu/prezto/issues/1239 the project moved to https://github.com/zsh-users/prezto

I see recent commits in the original repo from February and March, so this does not seem to be abandoned. Given the popularity of the source, I don't see a reason to link to a very young fork.

Maybe @sorin-ionescu himself can shed some light on this. If he's on board with the new community fork, I will merge this.

> I see recent commits in the original repo from February and March, so this does not seem to be abandoned. Given the popularity of the source, I don't see a reason to link to a very young fork.

Yep. 2016.. Anyway. Your decision. Just wanted to let you know.

And I don't think Sorin will answer here or join there. He didn't answer on the thread I mentioned (and which is about moving Prezto to the more official "zsh-users").
Would like to see this get merged.

I'm going to give @sorin-ionescu until the end of the month to reply with a short comment on the current state of his project. If there is no word from him, the community fork will will added in its place. Should I forget this, please feel free to remind me in April.
You could list both in the meantime. Would you be open to that?

@paulmelnikow why would that be relevant? Does any external project depend on that link being updated?

The author responded to the thread mentioned earlier, let's see if he wants to continue maintaining the project or not.

Exactly. Especially his mentioning of not even having received an email is worrying. Is the social media notification craze already at a point where people can't be bothered to write a single email any more? Real life interferes with the best of plans.

I'm just going to wait until the situation resolves itself. I bet they will all just merge everything back into the original repo and continue from there with several contributors.

Prezto is not abandoned, but it has been neglected publically for a year. I want to give write access to several volunteers. There are several forks, which need to be reconciled.

A GitHub notification subject line starts with `[user/repository]`, which often does not even fit in the threads column row of an email client, for example `Re: [herrbischoff/awesome-osx-command-li...`, let alone the issue title. I have hundreds of notification threads on Prezto alone. So, using GitHub notifications to get a hold of someone's attention is not effective. I wish @facastagnini or someone else that commented in https://github.com/sorin-ionescu/prezto/issues/1239 had sent me an email.

Thanks for your comment, @sorin-ionescu. That's what I figured. The sheer amount of notifications the sole maintainer of a popular open source project gets is staggering. If Real Life™ issues of any kind take the focus away for some time, getting back on top is an almost impossible task.

I view this as resolved and will leave the original repo in place as in all likelihood the changes made in other forks will be merged back into it with the help of additional volunteers.

Chapeau to your gut feeling @herrbischoff 

And good to see you around again @sorin-ionescu
fix broken path: remove erroneous space between `Launch` and `Daemons`
This is entirely correct. Merging. Thanks!

call the menu: 
<S_CODE_TOKEN>
screen:
![default](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5896784/23327162/380cf4be-fb42-11e6-93c0-c571dfb5e3ce.png)

A menuItem with a star means it's execuable, others are parent menu.
The menu is defined in msh.etc, and the corresponding function is defined in msh.fun.
Adding new menu or changing is very easy.

This is intriguing, thank you! :)

In the spirit of DRY: how about a function that is updating the script's content automatically? This is probably not possible in plain shell script as you would need to convert from Markdown to plain text. I don't see manually updating for every change happening. This would effectively be duplicating data and amounts to tedious work.
Although: https://github.com/chadbraunduin/markdown.bash

1. Gennerate shell script from Markdown.
It's not easy because the README.md is not that structured.
2. Generate Markdown from the shell content.
It's possible, if you agree with it, i'll give it a try with https://github.com/chadbraunduin/markdown.bash.

As I don't see this as feasible to support in the long run, I'm going to close the pull request. I don't want to discourage you, however the added maintenance and additional barrier of contributing will almost certainly not be worth it. This appears to be one of those ideas that sound neat in theory until you think through the long-term implications.

The `nettop` program displays a list of sockets or routes. The counts for network structures are updated periodically.

Very useful if you want to know which program uses what socket.

Thank you very much for your submission.

Please format your entry according to the rules specified in [contributing.md](https://github.com/herrbischoff/awesome-osx-command-line/blob/master/contributing.md), especially with regard to capitalization.

Also changed the string for the San Francisco font being inputed into the main font library of the machine.
Was about to propose the same changes, good fixes! 👍
Please split this. As per contribution guidelines there needs to be only one change per pull request.

As this needs to be installed via Homebrew before usage, it is not applicable to this list.

If that is the case, what are macvim, neovim, bash, fish, and zsh doing in the list? Thanks for the clarification.

P.S. You could add that to `contributing.md` to avoid future misunderstandings. Currently there's no indication anywhere that Homebrew should be avoided.

The shells are very basic necessities that are updated easily this way. The Vim versions are there because they are the most popular terminal text editors. Additionally, if I added this one utility, it would open the floodgates to argue for everyone's favorite shell tool to be included. Consider adding it to an applicable list, like <https://github.com/herrbischoff/awesome-command-line-apps>.

This adds a small note about the fundamental difference between the two package managers. Reuse vs. ensuring compatibility.

I tried to be neutral and just point out the difference, but I'm not sure if I succeeded or not, feedback is much welcome.

On that note, perhaps the personal note from the original author should be removed, as this serves as a guide for many new and old Mac tinkerers? I mean that whoever reads this should make an informed decision, and probably do their research, as you are pretty much stuck with your choice of package manager.

---

Personally I've used both MacPorts and Homebrew, and tried Fink. I found brew to be nicer, since it reuses the existing libraries, but that's just personal taste and MacPorts did a fine job when I did use it.
Thanks but I don't feel this is needed.
Could you elaborate, please?
> I mean that whoever reads this should make an informed decision, and probably do their research
Yes, what about it.
I found the additional info useful. I haven't thought about mac ports or fink in years. I just remember struggling with them, but didn't recall they had different philosophies

Is this truly just affecting Time Machine? It appears to be a debug setting completely ignoring low priority task settings. This is dangerous for anyone but a developer and appears to have many unintended side effects.

I stumbled upon this trick, as my backups did not finish in reasonable time. I guess this completely disables prioritization of the usual CPU allocation strategy. Nevertheless, my experience as well as the experience of other users of this command suggest, that there are no severe side effects happening. You should of course not use this command if you need to work under heavy CPU load... which _dangerous_ side effects do you see here?

As this is a `sysctl` setting that has system-wide consequences, it should be added under a new "System" section with an entry accurately describing its behavior. It may help boost Time Machine as a side-effect but as I understand it, it will disable low priority tasks altogether. This may very well lock up your machine completely if there is a stray process eating up lots of CPU cycles.

I am convinced that when Time Machine is not able to run successfully due to being a low priority task, the source of your troubles may be found elsewhere entirely.

I'm going to close this for now, eventually revisiting it after I have learned more about the settings' implications.

In "Disks and Volumes", you document using "bless" to set boot volume.

With the newly-introduced [System Integrity Protection](https://developer.apple.com/library/content/documentation/Security/Conceptual/System_Integrity_Protection_Guide/ConfiguringSystemIntegrityProtection/ConfiguringSystemIntegrityProtection.html) (appears to have been introduced with El Capitan), you must either disable it (using csrutil) or use the "[systemsetup](https://developer.apple.com/legacy/library/documentation/Darwin/Reference/ManPages/man8/systemsetup.8.html)" utility instead.

systemsetup -setstartupdisk "/path/to/mounted/volume"
Thanks! I will look into this and amend the respective entry.

Hi All,

Added Hyper (previously HyperTerm) as an electron alternative terminal. Pretty good backing atm, lots of themes and support for it.

https://github.com/zeit/hyper

Thanks for the recommendation. However, I feel that Hyper does nothing Terminal.app (and especially iTerm) does not do already. And they do it better. It's not faster, not more compatible, in essence, it offers no substantial benefit over the others. It's just coded in JavaScript for the sake of it. I see the trend of Electron web wrappers as a misguided one. Thanks anyway.
@herrbischoff Can I ask why you're against Electron-based apps?

Mainly because most of them are just web applications with no real integration into the OSs they run on. The way I see it, a notable application should leverage the underlying OSs strengths and not be a simple web view. Maybe the performance implications change if something like the [WebGPU proposal](https://webkit.org/blog/7380/next-generation-3d-graphics-on-the-web/) can be agreed upon but this still leaves the OS integration. For comparison, I doubt any advanced Linux/BSD/Solaris user is going to use a web-based terminal application for daily work. That's what xterm, urxvt and others are for. Hyper (and projects like Black Screen) appear to be for people who like to customize the terminal *looks* more than the actual *workflow*. Eye candy is nice, but substance is better.
They're bundled with Terminal.app, in `/Applications/Utilities/Terminal.app/Contents/Resources/Fonts`

They are also in the (non-beta) Xcode package, so `cp -v /Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/SharedFrameworks/DVTKit.framework/Versions/A/Resources/Fonts/SFMono-* ~/Library/Fonts` works fine for me with Xcode 8.2.1 on El Cap.

Good catch, both of you. I think I'm going to go with the Terminal.app variant as it does not require anything to be installed at all. The current entry was added at a time when the typeface was exclusively used in Xcode (and the then-beta version).

Mac Mail is using the folder path ~/Library/Mail/V4/ such that the script here needs to be updated.
The modified script has been checked with my own folder structure (osx sierra 10.12.3) and it worked.

Source:
http://brettterpstra.com/2015/10/27/vacuuming-mail-dot-app-on-el-capitan/

Another variant is documented here:
http://brettterpstra.com/2012/09/15/vacuuming-your-mail-app-index-still-works-wonders/
But I cannot verify which mac mail version (v3 or v4) is used on El Capitan.
Good catch, thank you!

What exactly does *not* work with the current approach?

The current approach doesn't work.  It runs `echo` with sudo permissions, but the pipe to `/etc/shells` is done as the current user.  And the current user might not have permissions to write to that file.

The current status for local backups can be found in the preferences file under the `MobileBackups` key.

The `DoNotOfferNewDisksForBackup` key should be set in /Library/Preferences/com.apple.TimeMachine, not in ~/Library/Preferences/com.apple.TimeMachine. This is where other Time Machine preferences are stored as well.
A sensible change, thanks!
`-g` is a shorthand for `NSGlobalDomain` or `-globalDomain`. This PR makes the usage consistent.

In my own tests, I have found it sufficient to change `ComputerName` and `LocalHostName` only. `HostName` is not set by default and `NetBIOSName` in the preference file is changed whenever `LocalHostName` is changed (although there may be a slight delay of a couple of seconds). Changing only these two names corresponds to what the user can do in System Preferences → Sharing.
This adds the command to enable the “Anywhere” setting of Gatekeeper. In Sierra, this GUI option is no longer present, but Terminal still has it.
I’ve added the changes as requested.

From this discussion on [StackExchange](http://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/45404/why-cant-tr-read-from-dev-urandom-on-osx): 

"Your tr attempts to interpret its input as text in UTF-8 encoding. So it will complain and abort upon the first byte sequence which is not valid UTF-8"

<S_CODE_TOKEN>
This indeed appears to be so, are you on Sierra? It worked without a hitch on El Capitan.
I am indeed on Sierra.
Well, something must have changed since then. I'm using an identical shell setup and this happens for me too. I will add a note to the entry and research this further.
Thanks!

According to the manpage of `tr`:

> The LANG, LC_ALL, LC_CTYPE and LC_COLLATE environment variables affect the execution of tr as described in environ(7).

As `tr` requires text files, if any charmap is set, it will have problems with a stream of binary data, as coming from `/dev/urandom`.

The correct command should therefore probably be:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Thank you for your suggestion. I was thinking about adding them a while back but did not, for the time being.

Do you feel that any of them is ready for prime time usage? It appears to me that those are at best early beta versions with a lot of work still to be done. Terminal.app itself is probably more capable than any of them. The idea of a HTML/CSS/JS-based terminal emulator is kind of intriguing but as of right now doesn't feel quite right to me. I'm absolutely open to arguments and to learn something new, so feel free to let me know what you think.

HyperTerm is useable (I've switched) but after trying Black Screen again I have to agree with you. I've also just discovered that Terminal.app has changed quite a bit from the last time I tried it.

Soo... feel free to close the PR or keep it around and merge it a few month. Thx for the excellent ressourcce!
Thanks for your feedback. I'm going to keep this open and check back in a couple of months if they improved noticeably.

As no significant progress has been made since August, I'm going to close this issue for now. We may revisit at a much later time, after HyperTerm and Black Screen have both pushed out a 1.0 version (currently at 0.8.3 and 0.2.79 respectively). I for one wouldn't call any of those terminal apps "awesome" as of now (and for the foreseeable future).

Additionally, I _really, really, really_ dislike Electron wrappers, aka bundled web apps.
Thanks for noticing and submitting a PR!

As soon as Sierra is officially released, change the name to `awesome-macos-command-line`.

**Update:** Lowest priority for now. I'm getting to it eventually but not right now.
@herrbischoff it's released;)

Ummm, I gave the idea a thumbs-down _because_
1. There are still a _lot_ of people who haven't upgraded/won't upgrade before 10.12.2 is out (at least); and
2. Renaming it from a long-used name would encourage new people to expect that the list was Sierra-specific when it's really not.

@jdickey: A valid and interesting point. I am not particularly partial to jumping on any new development. Long term however, this makes sense as Apple has officially renamed Mac OS X to macOS, for better or worse.

@jdickey Almost a [third on Sierra, 40% on El Capitan](https://www.gosquared.com/global/mac/sierra/#beta). I think it's safe to say that we can ignore Yosemite, since command line users are power users and have updated systems.

@napcae. Right. We're an El Capitan shop and have no expectation to even touch Sierra until 10.12.2+ reduces the support panic to normal levels _and_ all our critical tools support it. Neither of those conditions yet apply. Did they change the name of El Capitan and we just didn't notice? _That_ was my point.
I wonder why the name change appears to be such a thing of importance for some people. It's still OS X, it's just marketing. Gonna get to it later.

Alright, I'm closing the issue now.

Your permissions can still get messed up, and the new command to fix them is: sudo /usr/libexec/repair_packages --repair --standard-pkgs

This is new to El Capitan.

Thanks for this interesting catch. However, upon trying and researching it, it's about as (in)efficient as the "old" permission repair. It is not able to completely repair every instance it finds differing in permissions.

Also, when using Homebrew, it resets the user:group of `/usr/local` to `root:wheel`, effectively removing write permissions for the current user. This breaks Homebrew. I may add this to the collection with this result as a caveat.

Anyway, good catch!

This command was not new to El Capitan, it existed since permissions repair existed. The libexec directory normally contains binaries that are used by other programs, in this case presumably by Disk Utility itself. In El Capitan, Apple severed this usage and in Sierra they removed this command entirely. Even `pkgutil` can no longer repair packages (Apple seems to have forgotten to update this program).
Since the suggested command is entirely deprecated, I'm going to close this issue without adding it to the list.
Thanks. Could you please add a short explanation what exactly that command resp. the value `0` does.
@herrbischoff Seems good now.
Thanks again for your addition!
No problem!

I had a similar script in [my own dotfiles](https://github.com/TwP/dotfiles/blob/master/macos/defaults/keyboard#L43-L56), but alas, MacOS Sierra changed the way that keyboard mappings are handled. Short story is that `ioreg -n IOHIDKeyboard -r` no longer returns any results. This script will not work on Sierra.

Thanks for your submission. I will however not merge as OpenDNS is far more likely to remain online for the next decade than a random IP resolver. There are dozens of those curl-based services out there, but using the current technique will guarantee that it still works years from now.

Regarding the OS X-specific note: yes, some commands will invariably end up on this list that are common Unix commands. Their inclusion does not follow any strict rule. I will add them if I feel they provide context and/or are not generally known but exceedingly helpful.

sudo defaults write /System/Library/LaunchDaemons/com.apple.mDNSResponder ProgramArguments -array-add "-NoMulticastAdvertisements"
Fails with: defaults[379:4885] Could not write domain /System/Library/LaunchDaemons/com.apple.mDNSResponder; exiting
Ahh… This may very well be another instance of System Integrity Protection at work. You probably use El Capitan, correct?
I do indeed. I think the rest of the ones I did all worked fine.
Please see issue #39. Apparently adding `.plist` to the domain name does work.
Definitely doesn't work, even after running csrutil disable. I read the guy's post, but I can't replicate it.

After a little more work, I found a repeatable process.

In recovery, run 
`csrutil disable && reboot`
Once back in OS X, log in as an admin user and run 
`sudo launchctl unload /System/Library/LaunchDaemons/com.apple.mDNSResponder.plist`
`sudo defaults write /System/Library/LaunchDaemons/com.apple.mDNSResponder.plist ProgramArguments -array-add "-NoMulticastAdvertisements"`
`sudo launchctl load /System/Library/LaunchDaemons/com.apple.mDNSResponder.plist`
Reboot and go back into recovery and run
`csrutil enable && reboot`

That worked for me.
I could not convert my png to svg. I want to translate this great tool to Turkish.

However, I believe that people who are knowledgeable enough to use the shell on any Unix-based OS usually have a pretty good grasp of the English language. Otherwise using pretty much any system will prove to be a pain. English is the de-facto _lingua franca_ of the web. Whether that's deservedly so is a matter of debate. As it stands now, those are the facts.

Walter - did you do anything else? I can't replicate the fix that you did, even with SIP turned off.

After a little more work, I found a repeatable process.

In recovery, run 
csrutil disable && reboot
Once back in OS X, log in as an admin user and run 
sudo launchctl unload /System/Library/LaunchDaemons/com.apple.mDNSResponder.plist
sudo defaults write /System/Library/LaunchDaemons/com.apple.mDNSResponder.plist ProgramArguments -array-add "-NoMulticastAdvertisements"
sudo launchctl load /System/Library/LaunchDaemons/com.apple.mDNSResponder.plist
Reboot and go back into recovery and run
csrutil enable && reboot

That worked for me.

Didn't work for me.

mDNSResponder is still active and using RAM.

OS X 10.11.6

You do realize that mDNSResponder absolutely needs to run because it's the local macOS DNS client, do you? Right, didn't think so.

This command turns off picking up multicast advertisements (Zeroconf/Bonjour/Avahi). The fact that mDNSResponder still runs only indicates that you have been unsuccessful in mangling your system beyond usability but have otherwise probably achieved what you were looking for.

You should really know about what exactly these things do **before** you disable SIP and/or run system level commands you find on the internet.

Thanks for the reply - it's always nice to wake up to a snarky retort.
Thankfully my system hasn't been "mangled" so that I may respond.

BTW, you might investigate your Dictionary app sometime, because you used "mangled" incorrectly.

> severely mutilate, disfigure, or damage by cutting, tearing, or crushing.

I _thought_ mDNSResponder was necessary, but then while trying prevent more processes from calling home I ran across some pages discussing it and Bonjour and ways to disable it. Nowhere did they mention that mDNSResponder is essential and that entering the commands only disables the discovery ability, not actually mDNSResponder itself. Nor did they describe a method of testing to see if discovery was in fact disabled or not after entering the commands.

I'm not sure the steps are necessary anyway since checking the box to **Disable all incoming connections** in the firewall pane also blocks Bonjour.

This command allows users with FileVault protected drives to restart their machine without it prompting for an unlock key at startup. This is especially useful for people working remotely over SSH who do not have physical access to enter the unlock key after a reboot.

I just wondered about creating a subfolder in this repo with several additional files:
- A setup script, containing sane default settings for OS X
- An alias file containing useful command snippets and shortcuts to be sourced
- Separate alias files for functions and shortcuts for specific applications (as to give a home to solutions like #23) and environments

The idea is obviously influenced by [Mathias Bynens' repo](https://github.com/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/blob/master/.osx) but I'd like to go beyond it, creating a structured collection of settings, aliases and shortcuts. Kind of like commented master config files for OS X. For Unix tools that need a config file, often there is a sample file with comments, explaining the settings. That's what I have in mind.

What do you think?
Would also be good if we could run tests on the snippets. Maybe using Travis?

@vinkla: Interesting idea. Travis does support Mac OS as a testing target. However, writing effective tests for simple configuration changes could prove to be challenging, as there is usually no output. Also, Hardware-related tests will probably be impossible.
We could just create a script that is executed and see how well it performs on different versions of OS X. Take a look at this repository: https://github.com/mikemcquaid/strap
I see, so what you have in mind is a simple (global) check instead of adding tests for every snippet separately. ;)
Yeah, that will make it easier to implement :)

Alright. I will see if I find the time to work on the new content today. I'll leave the creation of the `.travis.yml` file to you. :) If you like, I'm going to add you as a collaborator when things are added and set up. This way you can trigger Travis builds at will.
Aaah, cool! Let me know when I can start :)

Alright, @vinkla: as of now you have push access to the repository. Use it wisely! ;)

I have set up a new branch `setup-files` for us to work with. I believe the structure should be self-explanatory. I use Vim as my main code editor so the files are tailored to this environment. To spare yourself and others the pain of having to adjust editor settings manually, there is also an `.editorconfig` file. Which should (given the correct plugin for your code editor is installed) adjust the code formatting automatically.

I believe the files should ultimately be in a separate folder which contains its own `README.md` with basic information about their intent and instructions on how to use them.

Let's see what we can create! I'm especially looking forward to how the Travis tests will run. They are set to run only when a `.travis.yml` file is present. So as soon as you add one, it's go time.
Alright! I'll get started directly :)

Prezto is a faster framework than Zsh. It's worthy of mentioning.

Thanks for the recommendation. As far as I can see, it appears to be quite limited and not really well documented. Did I miss something?

I'd welcome a lightweight OMZ alternative but I cannot seem to grasp its exact advantages.

I'm probably not the right guy to defend Prezto vs OhMyZsh, but I'd say Prezto is not as flexible or extensible as OMZ, but it still brings a lot of that Zsh power to play without the slowdown. It's still got a lot of what I would guess the majority of people use OMZ for.
As for documentation, yeah, the project is lacking, but there are many good posts on other sites detailing it.

- http://joshsymonds.com/blog/2014/06/12/shell-awesomeness-with-prezto/
- http://concreted.azurewebsites.net/custom-terminal-with-zshell-iterm-and-prezto/ (dated 3 Nov 2014)
